user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_find_match:
```c
static int lfs_dir_find_match(void *data,
        lfs_tag_t tag, const void *buffer) {
    struct lfs_dir_find_match *name = data;
    lfs_t *lfs = name->lfs;
    const struct lfs_diskoff *disk = buffer;

    // compare with disk
    lfs_size_t diff = lfs_min(name->size, lfs_tag_size(tag));
    int res = lfs_bd_cmp(lfs,
            NULL, &lfs->rcache, diff,
            disk->block, disk->off, name->name, diff);
    if (res != LFS_CMP_EQ) {
        return res;
    }

    // only equal if our size is still the same
    if (name->size != lfs_tag_size(tag)) {
        return (name->size < lfs_tag_size(tag)) ? LFS_CMP_LT : LFS_CMP_GT;
    }

    // found a match!
    return LFS_CMP_EQ;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_dir_find_match:
static inline lfs_size_t lfs_tag_size(lfs_tag_t tag) {
    return tag & 0x000003ff;
}
...
static int lfs_bd_cmp(lfs_t *lfs,
        const lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, lfs_size_t hint,
        lfs_block_t block, lfs_off_t off,
        const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    const uint8_t *data = buffer;
    lfs_size_t diff = 0;

    for (lfs_off_t i = 0; i < size; i += diff) {
        uint8_t dat[8];

        diff = lfs_min(size-i, sizeof(dat));
        int err = lfs_bd_read(lfs,
                pcache, rcache, hint-i,
                block, off+i, &dat, diff);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        int res = memcmp(dat, data + i, diff);
        if (res) {
            return res < 0 ? LFS_CMP_LT : LFS_CMP_GT;
        }
    }

    return LFS_CMP_EQ;
}
...
static int lfs_bd_read(lfs_t *lfs,
        const lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, lfs_size_t hint,
        lfs_block_t block, lfs_off_t off,
        void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    uint8_t *data = buffer;
    if (off+size > lfs->cfg->block_size
            || (lfs->block_count && block >= lfs->block_count)) {
        return LFS_ERR_CORRUPT;
    }

    while (size > 0) {
        lfs_size_t diff = size;

        if (pcache && block == pcache->block &&
                off < pcache->off + pcache->size) {
            if (off >= pcache->off) {
                // is already in pcache?
                diff = lfs_min(diff, pcache->size - (off-pcache->off));
                memcpy(data, &pcache->buffer[off-pcache->off], diff);

                data += diff;
                off += diff;
                size -= diff;
                continue;
            }

            // pcache takes priority
            diff = lfs_min(diff, pcache->off-off);
        }

        if (block == rcache->block &&
                off < rcache->off + rcache->size) {
            if (off >= rcache->off) {
                // is already in rcache?
                diff = lfs_min(diff, rcache->size - (off-rcache->off));
                memcpy(data, &rcache->buffer[off-rcache->off], diff);

                data += diff;
                off += diff;
                size -= diff;
                continue;
            }

            // rcache takes priority
            diff = lfs_min(diff, rcache->off-off);
        }

        if (size >= hint && off % lfs->cfg->read_size == 0 &&
                size >= lfs->cfg->read_size) {
            // bypass cache?
            diff = lfs_aligndown(diff, lfs->cfg->read_size);
            int err = lfs->cfg->read(lfs->cfg, block, off, data, diff);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }

            data += diff;
            off += diff;
            size -= diff;
            continue;
        }

        // load to cache, first condition can no longer fail
        LFS_ASSERT(!lfs->block_count || block < lfs->block_count);
        rcache->block = block;
        rcache->off = lfs_aligndown(off, lfs->cfg->read_size);
        rcache->size = lfs_min(
                lfs_min(
                    lfs_alignup(off+hint, lfs->cfg->read_size),
                    lfs->cfg->block_size)
                - rcache->off,
                lfs->cfg->cache_size);
        int err = lfs->cfg->read(lfs->cfg, rcache->block,
                rcache->off, rcache->buffer, rcache->size);
        LFS_ASSERT(err <= 0);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return 0;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
These three fragments form the only call chain in the provided code that could potentially produce indirect recursion: lfs_dir_find_match calls lfs_bd_cmp, which calls lfs_bd_read, which in turn invokes the function pointer lfs->cfg->read. The read callback is an external/indirect function pointer and could, in its implementation, call back into library functions (potentially lfs_* functions), creating indirect recursion. Therefore the implementation of the read callback and any functions it calls should be inspected for recursion.

Other code fragments need not be investigated for Rule 17.2 based on the provided code:
- lfs_tag_size is an inline bitmask extractor and cannot recurse.
- memcmp, memcpy and standard helpers (lfs_min, lfs_alignup, lfs_aligndown, LFS_ASSERT) are simple operations or library calls that do not call back into these functions.
- lfs_bd_cmp itself only calls lfs_bd_read and memcmp; it does not call lfs_dir_find_match or any other higher-level functions shown here.
- There are no other shown function-pointer invocations or call sites in the provided code that could create recursion besides lfs->cfg->read.

Focus investigation on the implementation(s) assigned to lfs->cfg->read and any functions reachable from it to detect direct or indirect self-calls.
